cards.front: What is a change of basis?
cards.back:
Converting how a vector is described between two different coordinate systems with different basis vectors.

The same geometric vector can have different numerical coordinates depending on your choice of basis.

cards.front: How do you translate coordinates from "their" basis to "your" basis?
cards.back:
Create a matrix P whose columns are their basis vectors expressed in your coordinates.

Multiply: (your coordinates) = P × (their coordinates)

cards.front: How do you translate from "your" basis to "their" basis?
cards.back:
Use the inverse matrix P⁻¹.

(their coordinates) = P⁻¹ × (your coordinates)

cards.front: What does the expression A⁻¹MA represent?
cards.back:
The same transformation M expressed in a different coordinate system.

1. A⁻¹: translate input to your coordinates
2. M: apply transformation in your coordinates
3. A: translate output to their coordinates

This is called a similarity transformation or conjugation.

cards.front: Why is change of basis useful?
cards.back:
Some bases make certain transformations simpler.

For example, choosing eigenvectors as a basis can turn a complex matrix into a simple diagonal matrix.
